page.title: 12Upper and Nether Padley
page.content: Around the Grindleford station, the area of Upper Padley is actually in the civil parish of Hathersage. The London, Midland and Scottish Railway actually brought about a growth of residental property in this area, and the tunnel now known as the Totley Tunnel cost Â£75 per yard to build, and due to the solid underground gritstone and the presence of water, only about 20 yards per week were tunneled. Padley Mill, once a large saw mill built on the Burbage brook, is now a private house. Nether Padley, being further down the hill towards the main Grindleford village centre, is a difficult name to define. In old English, the word 'PADDE' meant toad, and 'LEAN' was a clearing in a wood. However, many a persons name was used in the naming of a particular area.
